sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of lithium carbonate (Li2CO3)?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of lithium carbonate (Li2CO3), we need to add the molar masses of all the elements present in the compound.

Lithium (Li) has a molar mass of 6.94 g/mol. Since there are two lithium atoms in the compound, we multiply the molar mass by 2:
2 * 6.94 g/mol = 13.88 g/mol

Carbon (C) has a molar mass of 12.01 g/mol. There is only one carbon atom in the compound, so we don't need to multiply:
12.01 g/mol

Oxygen (O) has a molar mass of 16.00 g/mol. Since there are three oxygen atoms in the compound, we multiply the molar mass by 3:
3 * 16.00 g/mol = 48.00 g/mol

Now, we add the molar masses of all the elements:
13.88 g/mol (Li) + 12.01 g/mol (C) + 48.00 g/mol (O) = 73.89 g/mol

The molar mass of lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) is 73.89 g/mol.
